wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Knyazev Pro corporate videoproduction landing page. Explain its purpose as a business-oriented conversion tool designed to showcase video production capabilities, generate leads through consultation requests, and establish brand credibility. Document the architecture as a static, multi-page HTML site using vanilla JavaScript and CSS3 with no framework dependencies. Highlight key features including mobile-first responsive design, RuTube video integration, Google Analytics 4 tracking, and sessionStorage for cross-page data transfer. Include implementation details such as the use of CSS custom properties for theming, semantic HTML5 structure, and progressive enhancement principles. Provide practical examples from the codebase like the FOMO countdown timer, mini-brief modal form, and portfolio filtering system. Explain how components interact across pages and the role of each HTML file in the user journey from awareness to conversion.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for event handling in the landing page application. Explain how vanilla JavaScript is used to attach event listeners for critical user interactions including mobile menu toggle, portfolio filtering, accordion toggles, form submission, and CTA button clicks. Document the use of event delegation where applicable and describe how events are bound to DOM elements on page load within the IIFE structure. Include code examples showing addEventListener usage for click, touchstart, and submit events. Detail the implementation of event-specific behaviors such as preventing default form submission, handling one-time interactions for video autoplay fallback, and tracking user actions via analytics. Address accessibility considerations like aria-expanded state management and keyboard navigation support. Explain error handling patterns for failed event execution and provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like unresponsive buttons or missing event bindings.

wiki_catalogs.name: CSS Custom Properties
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the CSS custom properties (variables) defined in the :root selector. Explain their role in enabling consistent theming and easy customization across the landing page. Detail each variable including --bg, --bg-2, --card, --text, --muted, --line, and --brand, describing their intended usage context (e.g., background colors, text colors, borders, accents). Illustrate how these variables are applied across components such as buttons, cards, sections, and forms. Provide examples from styles.css showing variable usage in .btn-primary, .section-dark, and .service-card. Explain the benefits of using CSS variables for maintainability and theming, and how they support the dark theme implementation. Include guidance on how to modify or extend the theme by updating these variables.

wiki_catalogs.name: Navigation Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for the navigation component system used across all pages. Explain the implementation of the responsive header with mobile hamburger menu, desktop navigation links, and logo branding. Document the HTML structure using semantic elements like header, nav, and button with proper ARIA attributes (aria-expanded, aria-label). Describe the JavaScript functionality in assets/main.js that handles mobile menu toggle, click outside closure, and link navigation. Include examples from index.html showing the dual-header pattern (hero-nav and contact-header). Address accessibility considerations including keyboard navigation and screen reader support. Provide guidance on maintaining consistent navigation behavior and styling across all pages through shared CSS classes and JavaScript event handling.

wiki_catalogs.name: Event Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the event tracking implementation using the trackEvent function in main.js. Explain how custom events are pushed to the dataLayer for Google Analytics 4 integration, including the structure of event parameters (category, action, label). Document all tracked interactions such as button clicks (mini-brief, open-portfolio, scroll-to-consultation), accordion toggles (product includes and examples), and portfolio filtering. Provide code examples showing how data attributes like data-action trigger events and how event payloads are constructed. Include debugging strategies using browser developer tools to inspect dataLayer pushes and verify event correctness. Address best practices for event naming conventions and performance considerations when tracking high-frequency interactions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mobile Navigation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the mobile navigation system. Explain the implementation of the hamburger menu toggle with the mobileMenuToggle button and navMenu elements, including the CSS transitions for the three-line icon animation and menu slide-in effect. Document the JavaScript event handlers that toggle the 'active' class on both the toggle button and navigation menu. Describe the functionality that closes the menu when a navigation link is clicked or when clicking outside the menu area. Include the responsive CSS media queries that control the mobile menu display on screens below 1024px. Provide examples from the code showing how touch and click events are used to handle user interactions across different devices. Address common issues like iOS viewport bugs and provide troubleshooting guidance for menu positioning and backdrop filter compatibility.

wiki_catalogs.name: Mobile Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on mobile optimization strategies. Detail the implementation of iOS-specific fixes including the 100vh viewport issue using -webkit-fill-available within @supports blocks, touch-action manipulation to eliminate 300ms click delay, and -webkit-overflow-scrolling for smooth inertial scrolling on iOS. Explain Android video autoplay solutions with poster attributes, preload settings, and JavaScript fallbacks for muted playback. Document overflow-x: hidden enforcement across html, body, and container elements to prevent horizontal scrolling, and the critical distinction between 100vw and 100% to avoid layout overflow. Include the unified viewport meta tag configuration applied across all HTML pages and the responsive adjustments for mobile menus, CTA buttons, and form elements at 680px breakpoint. Reference MOBILE_OPTIMIZATION_FULL.md for version history and testing checklist, and IOS_MAC_OPTIMIZATION.md for platform-specific CSS and JavaScript fallbacks.

wiki_catalogs.name: Asset Loading
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on asset loading strategies implemented in the project. Explain critical CSS inlining techniques using a single optimized styles.css file (5.3KB) to minimize render-blocking resources. Detail deferred JavaScript execution through vanilla JS loading at the end of the document flow without async/defer conflicts. Cover preload hints for key assets like the hero video and Montserrat Variable Font using appropriate link rel attributes. Describe the strategy of embedding critical styles directly in HTML where applicable and lazy-loading non-essential resources. Include practical examples from the codebase such as the hero video preload implementation and font loading via @font-face with font-display:swap. Address fallback mechanisms for font loading and video playback initiation on mobile devices. Document performance impact measurements including First Contentful Paint (FCP ~1.2s) and how asset loading optimizations contributed to this metric. Provide recommendations for production environments including HTTP/2 push for critical assets and resource hints like dns-prefetch for external domains (RuTube, Google Analytics).

wiki_catalogs.name: Home Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the Home Page (index.html) of the Knyazev PRO videoproduction studio landing page. Explain the purpose of the page as the primary entry point designed for conversion and brand presentation. Detail the hero section with video background, overlay, and watermark, including responsive video handling and fallback poster image. Describe the navigation header with mobile menu toggle and persistent brand logo. Document the services grid with four service cards (Advertising, Product Videos, Event Videos, Explainer Videos) and their visual design using placeholder images. Explain the portfolio preview section that dynamically renders video cases from sessionStorage data. Outline the team section featuring four key personnel with photos and roles. Detail the consultation CTA section with form fields and submission handling. Describe the FOMO countdown timer that creates urgency for booking. Include user journey mapping from initial landing to form submission, highlighting key CTAs and conversion paths. Provide practical examples from the actual code including the use of dialog for the mini-brief modal, schema.org structured data, and smooth scrolling behavior. Address accessibility considerations such as aria-labels and semantic HTML structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Technology Stack & Dependencies
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the frontend technology stack of the Landing project. Detail the use of HTML5 for semantic, SEO-friendly markup; CSS3 with modern features including Flexbox, Grid, Custom Properties (variables), and animations for styling and responsive behavior; and vanilla JavaScript (ES6+) for all interactivity without external libraries. Document external dependencies including RuTube for video embedding, Google Tag Manager and Google Analytics 4 for event tracking and user behavior analysis, and sessionStorage for client-side data persistence. Explain the rationale behind choosing a dependency-free architecture for performance and maintainability. Include practical examples from the codebase such as CSS variable usage in :root declarations, event listeners in main.js, and iframe integration patterns for RuTube. Address browser compatibility requirements and optimization techniques like variable fonts and lazy loading.

wiki_catalogs.name: DOM Manipulation
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for DOM manipulation techniques used in main.js. Describe how the script queries and modifies the DOM to implement dynamic features such as mobile menu visibility, portfolio item display toggling, modal dialog rendering, and countdown timer updates. Explain the use of methods like querySelector, getElementById, classList.toggle, setAttribute, and innerHTML for updating UI states. Include practical examples from the codebase such as filtering case items by data-category attribute, dynamically creating iframe embeds for RuTube videos, and manipulating modal display styles for older browser compatibility. Document the fallback strategies for browsers lacking modern APIs like showModal(). Address performance considerations when manipulating multiple elements and provide best practices for minimizing reflows and repaints. Include debugging tips for identifying DOM update issues and ensuring cross-browser consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this section explaining the mobile-first responsive design strategy implemented in the project. Describe the defined breakpoints: mobile (<680px), tablet (680-1024px), and desktop (>1024px), and how layout adjustments are handled via media queries in styles.css. Cover key responsive behaviors including the transformation of the two-column layout to single-column, grid adjustments for services, portfolio, and pricing sections, and the mobile navigation menu toggle. Explain the use of fluid grids, flexible images, and viewport units (vh, vw) for adaptive layouts. Highlight special considerations for iOS Safari including the 100vh fix using -webkit-fill-available and scroll behavior optimizations. Include practical examples from the CSS showing responsive adjustments for .hero, .services-grid, .case-list, and .mobile-menu-toggle. Address performance implications and best practices for responsive design in static sites.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the portfolio component system that enables video showcase and filtering. Explain the implementation of the case-filters button group with data-filter attributes and active state management. Document the dynamic rendering of case-item elements containing RuTube iframes through JavaScript in portfolio.html's inline script and assets/main.js. Describe the data flow from sessionStorage videoSegments object to DOM rendering, including fallback mechanisms. Detail the filtering logic that shows/hides items based on data-category attributes. Include examples from portfolio.html showing the responsive grid layout and category-specific video embedding. Address performance considerations for lazy loading videos and memory management of sessionStorage data. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like missing videos or broken filtering.

wiki_catalogs.name: CRM Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the CRM integration via the sendToCRM function in main.js. Explain how lead data from the mini-brief modal form is collected, structured, and prepared for transmission to external CRM systems like AmoCRM or Bitrix24. Detail the data flow from form submission to JSON payload creation, including UTM parameter capture from URL queries. Describe the current implementation as a stub using fetch() with a placeholder webhook URL and proper Content-Type headers. Provide guidance on configuring the actual CRM endpoint and handling CORS requirements. Include error handling strategies, success feedback mechanisms (console logs, alerts), and security considerations for transmitting sensitive client data. Offer practical examples for extending the function with authentication tokens or additional metadata.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Filtering
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the portfolio filtering mechanism. Explain how the filter buttons with data-filter attributes interact with the case-items to show/hide portfolio entries based on category. Document the JavaScript implementation that removes the 'active' class from all buttons and adds it to the clicked button, then iterates through case-items to set display style based on category matching. Describe the videoSegments object structure that categorizes RuTube video IDs by industry, brand, events, travel, sport, and PR. Include the CSS styling for filter buttons, including active state visualization with background color changes and icon brightness adjustments. Provide examples from the code showing how the trackEvent function logs filter interactions. Address performance considerations for rendering large numbers of portfolio items and troubleshooting guidance for iframe loading issues in different browsers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Tablet Layouts
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on tablet-responsive design at the 1024px breakpoint. Explain the layout transformations from desktop to tablet including the two-column section collapsing into single-column via grid-template-columns: 1fr, services grid changing from 4-column to 2-column layout, portfolio case list reducing from 3-column to 2-column grid, and director cards shifting from 4-column to 2-column arrangement. Document the background image size adjustments using media queries to scale from cover to 900px auto for optimal tablet display. Describe the typography adjustments with reduced hero font sizes (48px → 40px) and paragraph sizing. Include the responsive behavior of client logos grid switching from horizontal flex to wrapped layout. Provide practical examples from the CSS media queries and demonstrate how these changes create an optimal viewing experience on iPad and similar tablet devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Code Splitting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section focused on code splitting and modularization in a vanilla JavaScript environment. Explain how the project achieves optimal performance without traditional code splitting tools by maintaining a single, highly optimized main.js file (8.9KB) that avoids external dependencies. Detail the procedural modular pattern using IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression) to encapsulate functionality and prevent global namespace pollution. Break down the logical separation of concerns within main.js including mobile menu handling, portfolio filtering, form submission, and analytics tracking as de facto modules. Describe how functionality is conditionally executed based on DOM element presence rather than dynamic import patterns. Include concrete examples from the codebase such as the isolated implementation of smoothScrollTo with fallback for iOS devices and the modular event binding for different CTA buttons. Address the trade-offs between true code splitting and this monolithic but lightweight approach, emphasizing the benefits for a small-scale application in terms of reduced HTTP requests and faster execution. Provide guidance on when to consider actual code splitting for larger applications and how to extend the current architecture if needed.

wiki_catalogs.name: Portfolio Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Portfolio Page (portfolio.html) of the videoproduction studio. Thoroughly explain the implementation of the filtering interface with eight category buttons (Presentation, Brand Films, Event, Travel, Sport Car, PR, New Projects, All Projects) and their active state management. Detail the JavaScript functionality that retrieves video segment data from sessionStorage or uses fallback data, including the videoSegments object structure with RuTube video IDs categorized by type. Explain the dynamic rendering of case items using JavaScript to create article elements with embedded RuTube iframes. Document the filtering mechanism that listens for button clicks, updates active states, and shows/hides case items based on data-category attributes. Describe the URL hash-based filter persistence that allows deep linking to specific categories. Include concrete examples from the code showing how iframe embeds are created with proper security attributes (allow, referrerPolicy). Explain the relationship between this page and the home page's sessionStorage data transfer. Address common issues such as failed sessionStorage retrieval and provide solutions. Include performance considerations for lazy loading videos and accessibility of the filtering interface.

wiki_catalogs.name: Component Architecture
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the UI component architecture of the landing page. Describe how the site is structured as a collection of reusable, consistent components across five main pages: Home (index.html), Portfolio, Pricing, Contact, and Founder. Document the navigation component (header with hamburger menu on mobile), footer with social links, CTA buttons, service cards, team member profiles, and client logo grids. Explain the implementation of interactive elements such as modals, accordions, and filters using semantic HTML and CSS/JS. Provide examples from actual page structures showing how components are instantiated and styled. Include guidance on maintaining visual consistency through shared CSS classes and layout patterns. Address accessibility considerations like ARIA attributes and keyboard navigation where applicable.

wiki_catalogs.name: Data Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for data management in the application, focusing on the use of JavaScript objects and sessionStorage for state persistence. Explain the structure and purpose of the videoSegments object used for categorizing portfolio videos and how it enables category-based filtering. Detail how rutubeIdsUnique stores deduplicated video identifiers and is passed between pages via sessionStorage to maintain consistent portfolio data. Describe the lead object structure used in form submissions and how it captures UTM parameters from the URL. Document the serialization and storage process using JSON.stringify() and the try-catch pattern for handling quota exceeded errors. Include usage examples showing data retrieval on portfolio.html and explain how this client-side storage approach enables state transfer without server-side sessions. Address limitations, security considerations, and alternatives for larger datasets.

wiki_catalogs.name: Typography
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed documentation for the typographic system used in the landing page. Explain the implementation of the Montserrat Variable Font via @font-face declarations, covering both regular and italic variants with weight ranges from 100 to 900. Describe how font-display:swap is used to ensure text remains visible during font loading. Detail the typographic hierarchy including h1 through p elements, with specific font weights, sizes, and letter-spacing values for each. Explain the use of system-ui fonts as fallbacks for performance and accessibility. Provide examples from styles.css showing font-size declarations for .hero h1, .section-title, and .content-left h2. Discuss the benefits of variable fonts for reducing HTTP requests and enabling fine-grained typographic control. Include guidance on how to modify font styles or substitute alternative typefaces while maintaining visual consistency.

wiki_catalogs.name: Pricing Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for the pricing component system that displays service packages and pricing information. Explain the implementation of product-card elements with tiered pricing (STANDART/PREMIUM) and expandable details via accordion toggles. Document the HTML structure using semantic sections, buttons with aria-expanded states, and responsive grid layouts. Describe the visual design including price-badge styling, product-includes and product-examples content areas. Include examples from price.html showing the products-grid layout and interactive toggle buttons that reveal service inclusions and portfolio examples. Address accessibility considerations for screen readers and keyboard navigation through expandable content. Provide guidance on adding new product cards while maintaining visual consistency and responsive behavior across devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Third-party Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for third-party integrations including Google Tag Manager and RuTube. Explain the preconnect directive to googletagmanager.com in the HTML head for improved analytics loading performance. Detail the initialization sequence for GA4 through gtag.js (not implemented but referenced) and its relationship with the dataLayer used by trackEvent. Cover the RuTube video embedding mechanism using iframe src templates with video IDs, including allow attributes for autoplay and fullscreen. Discuss cross-origin considerations, referrer policies, and privacy implications of embedding third-party content. Provide implementation examples for adding new integrations such as Yandex.Metrica (commented in code) and troubleshooting common issues like blocked iframes or failed script loads.

wiki_catalogs.name: Accordion Toggles
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the accordion toggle functionality used in product details and examples. Explain the JavaScript event listeners on product-includes-toggle and product-examples-toggle buttons that manage the expanded/collapsed state using ARIA attributes and CSS classes. Document how the toggle function updates the 'aria-expanded' attribute, toggles the 'expanded' class on content elements, and rotates the toggle-icon. Describe the CSS transitions that animate max-height and opacity for smooth opening/closing effects. Include the styling for hover states, focus outlines, and visual feedback. Provide examples from the code showing how the trackEvent function logs toggle interactions. Address accessibility considerations for screen readers and keyboard navigation, and provide troubleshooting guidance for transition timing issues and content overflow problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Desktop Layouts
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on desktop layout architecture. Describe the foundational grid systems including the 4-column services-grid (grid-template-columns: repeat(4,1fr)), 3-column case-list, and 4-column directors-grid that define the desktop experience. Explain the two-column section layout using CSS Grid with equal fractional units and 48px gap for balanced content presentation. Detail the typographic hierarchy with 48px section titles, 48px hero headings, and 18px body text optimized for larger screens. Document the desktop-specific interactive elements including hover effects on buttons (transform: translateY(-1px)), service cards, and filter buttons. Explain the fixed corner logo behavior and desktop navigation styling with inline-flex contact-nav and pipe-separated list items. Include the background image treatment at full cover size and the container-based layout system with 1200px max-width and 24px padding. Provide examples from the CSS source showing how these elements combine to create a professional desktop interface for the video production studio.

wiki_catalogs.name: Image Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature or sub-component section focused on image and video optimization practices in the landing page. Explain the implementation of WebP format usage for all static images where supported, with appropriate fallbacks for older browsers. Detail proper dimension handling through CSS object-fit:cover and fixed height specifications to prevent layout shifts. Cover lazy loading techniques for RuTube iframes using native iframe loading attributes and conditional rendering based on user interaction rather than scroll position. Describe the optimization of the hero video background with proper encoding settings (H.264, 1920×1080) and the use of playsinline attributes for mobile playback. Include the implementation of the fixed-corner logo with opacity transitions and its impact on perceived performance. Address font optimization through the use of Montserrat Variable Font, loading a single TTF file that supports all weights (100-900) instead of multiple static files, significantly reducing HTTP requests. Document the performance benefits including Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS ~0.05) improvements from proper image sizing and the impact on Largest Contentful Paint (LCP ~2.1s). Provide practical examples from the codebase such as the CSS rules for .hero-video and .fixed-corner-logo, and the JavaScript implementation of video autoplay with fallbacks for iOS devices.

wiki_catalogs.name: Price Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Price Page (price.html) of the videoproduction studio. Thoroughly explain the products and pricing section with six product cards (Advertising, Presentation, Brand Film, Event Overview, Image, Social Media Cuts) each containing dual pricing tiers (Standard and Premium). Detail the expandable accordion toggles for 'Подробнее' (Details) and 'Смотреть' (View Examples) using aria-expanded attributes for accessibility. Document the products grid layout and price badge styling. Explain the additional services section with pricing for editing, drone, voiceover, motion/CG, casting, and travel. Describe the process timeline section with four steps (Brief, Preproduction, Production, Postproduction) and their visual numbering. Detail the benefits grid with five cards highlighting status, clarity, media readiness, testability, and content scalability. Explain the target audience section with three columns (Who Orders, When Relevant, Output). Include concrete examples from the code showing RuTube video links in the examples section and the use of data-action attributes for CTAs. Address the relationship between pricing information and portfolio examples. Provide guidance on updating pricing information and adding new product categories. Include performance considerations for page load with multiple CTAs and accessibility of accordion controls.

wiki_catalogs.name: Styling Strategy
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the CSS architecture and styling approach. Detail the use of CSS Custom Properties (variables) defined in :root for theming (e.g., --bg, --text, --brand) enabling easy customization. Explain the mobile-first responsive design using media queries at defined breakpoints (mobile: <680px, tablet: 680-1024px, desktop: >1024px). Document the typographic system using Montserrat Variable Font for efficient loading across weights. Describe layout techniques using Flexbox and Grid for alignment and structure. Cover the dark theme implementation with pattern overlays and color contrast considerations. Include examples from styles.css showing component-specific styling, transitions, and responsive adjustments. Address performance optimizations like minimizing reflows and using efficient selectors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Utility Functions
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for utility functions implemented in main.js. Focus on the smoothScrollTo function that provides cross-browser support for smooth scrolling with fallback for older iOS versions lacking scrollBehavior support. Explain how the function detects feature support and delegates to native scrollIntoView with appropriate options. Document the countdown timer implementation that calculates and displays remaining days and hours until the next booking window, including how it updates the DOM every minute. Describe the trackEvent function used for analytics integration with Google Tag Manager and potential Yandex.Metrica support, detailing its parameters and dataLayer push pattern. Include the sendToCRM stub function that demonstrates how form data would be sent to a backend webhook. Provide examples of how these utilities are invoked throughout the codebase and explain their role in enhancing user experience and enabling monitoring. Offer optimization suggestions and error handling improvements.

wiki_catalogs.name: Color Scheme
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop comprehensive content focused on the color scheme implementation, particularly the dark theme design. Explain the use of background images with logo patterns overlayed via linear-gradient for visual depth while maintaining readability. Detail the color contrast considerations between text and background (e.g., var(--text) on var(--bg)) to meet accessibility standards. Describe the implementation of section backgrounds in .section-dark and .section-light using layered backgrounds with logo patterns at different color variations (E0E0E0 black.jpg, 0A0A0A beige.jpg). Explain how opacity and background-size adjustments are made for different screen sizes in media queries. Cover the use of accent colors like --brand (#B09B7E) for buttons, borders, and interactive elements to create visual hierarchy. Include examples of color application in .btn-primary, .case-filters .active, and segment themes (industry-theme, fmcg-theme, events-theme). Provide guidance on maintaining color consistency and accessibility when extending the design.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the form component system used for lead generation and consultation requests. Explain the implementation of the mini-brief modal dialog with dialog element and form controls including select inputs, text fields, and URL inputs. Document the consultation-form on the home page with input validation and submission handling. Describe the JavaScript functionality in assets/main.js that manages modal opening/closing, form submission to CRM via sendToCRM function, and event tracking. Include examples from index.html showing the mini-brief-form structure and data-action attributes. Address accessibility considerations including proper labeling, focus management, and error handling. Provide guidance on form field customization and integration with external CRM systems while maintaining consistent user experience.

wiki_catalogs.name: Form Handling
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the form handling system, focusing on the mini-brief modal implementation. Explain the JavaScript that shows the modal using showModal() with fallback for older browsers using the 'open' attribute. Document the form submission process that collects FormData, adds UTM parameters, and calls sendToCRM with the lead object. Describe the trackEvent integration that logs form submissions and the user feedback with alert messages. Include the CSS styling for the modal, form inputs, and responsive layout. Provide examples from the code showing the miniBriefQuestions array and form validation approach. Address security considerations for form submissions, browser compatibility issues (especially iOS < 15.4), and troubleshooting guidance for common problems like form not closing after submission or CRM integration failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Contact Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Contact Page (contact.html) of the videoproduction studio. Thoroughly explain the three main sections: primary contact information (phone, email, Telegram), social media presence (VK, RuTube, Yandex.Dzen, TenChat, Telegram channel), and legal information (individual entrepreneur details). Detail the contact information block with properly formatted tel and mailto links. Document the social networks list with external links and visual arrow indicators. Explain the legal section containing the full name of the individual entrepreneur (Alexey Vladimirovich Knyazev), INN (701713585138), and OGRNIP (324700000057063). Include concrete examples from the code showing the use of semantic HTML for contact data and proper target="_blank" attributes for external links. Address accessibility considerations such as link purpose and keyboard navigation. Explain the relationship between this page and the global footer navigation. Provide guidance on updating contact information and adding new social media platforms. Include security considerations for displaying personal data and compliance with Russian legal requirements for individual entrepreneurs.

wiki_catalogs.name: JavaScript Functionality
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the vanilla JavaScript implementation in main.js. Explain the procedural, IIFE-wrapped structure of the code and its separation of concerns into DOM manipulation, event handling, and utility functions. Detail core functionalities including mobile menu toggle with click/outside interactions, portfolio filtering with category-based video loading from the videoSegments object, accordion toggles for service details, and form submission via sendToCRM function. Document the use of sessionStorage to pass data between pages and the trackEvent function for analytics. Include code examples showing event listeners, DOM queries, class manipulation, and error handling. Address fallback implementations for older browsers and accessibility considerations like aria-expanded attributes.

wiki_catalogs.name: Utility Components
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for the utility components that enhance user experience across the site. Explain the implementation of the FOMO countdown timer that dynamically calculates remaining days to next month. Document the smooth scrolling behavior with fallback for older browsers using JavaScript in assets/main.js. Describe the modal dialog system used for the mini-brief form with proper dialog element semantics and accessibility attributes. Include examples of CTA buttons with consistent styling through btn classes and data-action triggers. Address the responsive container system and two-column layouts used in consultation sections. Provide guidance on implementing new utility features while maintaining performance and accessibility standards, including proper event delegation and graceful degradation for JavaScript-disabled environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Founder Page
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for this sub-feature focused on the Founder Page (founder.html) of the videoproduction studio. Thoroughly explain the personal profile of Alexey Knyazev as the founder and creative director. Detail the visual layout with full-width photo, name, roles (Director | Screenwriter | Cinematographer), and email link. Document the personal message section with three paragraphs describing the founder's approach to filmmaking based on real stories, emphasis on authenticity, and belief in emotional storytelling. Explain the centered content design using contact-centered and contact-inner classes. Include concrete examples from the code showing the use of semantic paragraphs and proper email linking. Address the relationship between this page and the team section on the home page. Provide guidance on updating the founder's message and credentials. Include accessibility considerations for image alt text and text readability. Explain how this page establishes credibility and personal connection with potential clients, serving as a trust-building element in the conversion funnel.

wiki_catalogs.name: Page Structure
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the structure and purpose of each HTML page in the application. Describe the Home Page (index.html) with its hero video, services grid, portfolio preview, team section, and consultation CTA. Detail the Portfolio Page (portfolio.html) with its filtering interface and RuTube video embedding system. Explain the Price Page (price.html) with service packages, expandable details, process timeline, and benefits section. Outline the Contact Page (contact.html) with contact information, social media links, and legal details. Describe the Founder Page (founder.html) with personal biography and credibility-building content. For each page, document the HTML structure, key sections, and interaction points with CSS and JavaScript. Include user journey mapping from entry points to conversion actions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Interactive Features
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the interactive elements that drive user engagement and conversion. Detail the Mobile Navigation system with hamburger menu toggle, menu closing on link click and outside click, and smooth scrolling. Explain the Portfolio Filtering mechanism that dynamically shows/hides videos by category with visual feedback. Describe the Accordion Toggles used for expanding service details and examples with proper ARIA state management. Document the Form Handling process including the mini-brief modal, input validation, CRM webhook submission, and confirmation feedback. Include implementation details from both JavaScript (event handlers, DOM updates) and CSS (transitions, active states). Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like iOS viewport bugs or iframe loading failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Analytics & Tracking
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the analytics and tracking implementation. Document the Google Analytics 4 integration via gtag.js in the HTML head and the custom trackEvent function in main.js for capturing user interactions like button clicks, form submissions, and page views. Explain the CRM integration through the sendToCRM function that sends lead data to external systems (AmoCRM, Bitrix24, etc.). Detail the use of dataLayer for event pushing and proper initialization sequence. Include examples of event naming conventions and payload structures. Address privacy considerations and compliance with data protection regulations. Provide debugging tips using browser developer tools to verify event firing and payload accuracy.

wiki_catalogs.name: Responsive Design
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the responsive and cross-platform compatibility strategy. Detail the mobile-first approach with breakpoints at 680px and 1024px, using CSS media queries to adapt layouts for mobile, tablet, and desktop. Explain specific optimizations for iOS and macOS including the 100vh viewport fix, touch-action improvements, backdrop-filter with WebKit prefixes, and smooth scrolling fallbacks. Document the testing methodology across browsers (Safari, Chrome, Firefox, Edge) and devices (iPhone, iPad, Android, Windows, Mac). Include performance considerations like lazy loading iframes and optimized asset delivery. Reference the MOBILE_OPTIMIZATION_FULL.md and IOS_MAC_OPTIMIZATION.md files for platform-specific implementation details and known issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Performance Optimization
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the performance optimization techniques implemented in the project. Document asset loading strategies including critical CSS inlining, deferred JavaScript execution, and preload hints for key resources. Explain code-level optimizations such as minified but readable CSS (5.3KB) and JavaScript (8.9KB), avoidance of external dependencies, and efficient DOM queries. Cover image and video optimization practices like WebP format usage, proper dimensions, and lazy loading of RuTube iframes. Address font optimization through Montserrat Variable Font loading a single file for all weights. Include Core Web Vitals metrics (FCP ~1.2s, LCP ~2.1s, CLS ~0.05) and how they were achieved. Provide recommendations for production deployment including Gzip/Brotli compression, CDN usage, and caching strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Deployment Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on deploying the Landing project to production environments. Document the simple deployment process due to its static nature—upload all files to any web server or hosting platform. List recommended platforms including Netlify (drag-and-drop or CLI), Vercel (vercel --prod), and GitHub Pages (repository settings). Provide traditional hosting instructions for FTP/SFTP upload with proper file permissions (644 for files, 755 for directories). Include configuration requirements for MIME types, especially for video and font files. Detail post-deployment verification steps such as checking console errors, testing forms, and validating analytics tracking. Address domain configuration and SSL setup through CDNs like Cloudflare. Reference the README.md for quick start commands using Python, Node.js, or PHP for local testing before deployment.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: Князев ПРО Landing

## 1. Project Introduction

**Purpose Statement**  
The project is a professional videoproduction studio landing page designed to showcase services, portfolio, pricing, and contact information for Князев ПРО, a video production company specializing in brand films, promotional videos, and PR content.

**Core Goals and Objectives**  
- Present the studio's capabilities and value proposition to potential clients
- Convert visitors through consultation requests and brief submissions
- Showcase portfolio work organized by category (brand films, events, PR, etc.)
- Provide clear pricing information and service offerings
- Establish credibility through team presentation and client logos

**Target Audience**  
- Marketing and PR directors
- Business owners and executives
- Production agencies
- Companies preparing for tenders, investor presentations, or product launches
- Brands seeking to enhance their visual identity and storytelling

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a static single-page application architecture with multiple HTML pages that share common assets and functionality. The core components include:

- **Main Pages**: `index.html`, `portfolio.html`, `price.html`, `contact.html`, `founder.html`
- **Assets**: CSS styling, JavaScript functionality, fonts, images, and video content
- **Interactive Elements**: Mobile navigation, portfolio filtering, price accordion toggles, and contact forms

### Design Patterns
The implementation follows several key design patterns:

- **Component-Based Structure**: Reusable UI components (buttons, cards, navigation) across pages
- **Progressive Enhancement**: Core functionality works without JavaScript, with enhanced interactions when available
- **Mobile-First Responsive Design**: Layouts adapt from mobile to desktop using CSS media queries
- **Session Storage Pattern**: Portfolio data is passed between pages using `sessionStorage`

### System Relationships
```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[Client] --> B[HTML Pages]
  B --> C[CSS Styling]
  B --> D[JavaScript Functionality]
  C --> E[Responsive Design]
  D --> F[Interactive Features]
  F --> G[Portfolio Filtering]
  F --> H[Form Handling]
  F --> I[Modal Management]
  B --> J[Media Assets]
  J --> K[Videos]
  J --> L[Images]
  J --> M[Fonts]
```

### Data Flow
```mermaid
flowchart TD
  A[User Interaction] --> B{Event Handler}
  B --> C[DOM Manipulation]
  C --> D[Visual Feedback]
  E[Page Load] --> F[Data Initialization]
  F --> G[Portfolio Data Setup]
  G --> H[Render Portfolio Items]
  I[Form Submission] --> J[Data Collection]
  J --> K[CRM Integration]
  K --> L[Confirmation]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- `index.html` - Primary landing page with hero section and call-to-action
- `portfolio.html` - Portfolio showcase with filtering capabilities
- `price.html` - Service pricing and process information
- `contact.html` - Contact information and communication channels
- `founder.html` - Team member profile and personal message

### Core Modules
- **assets/main.js** - Central JavaScript functionality
- **assets/styles.css** - Global styling and responsive design
- **assets/fonts/** - Custom typography resources
- **assets/img/** - Visual assets including logos, patterns, and photographs

### Configuration Approach
- **CSS Variables**: Theme colors and styling defined in `:root` variables
- **Data Attributes**: Used for JavaScript event handling and tracking
- **Inline Configuration**: Portfolio video IDs and categories defined directly in JavaScript

### External Dependencies
- **RuTube**: Video embedding platform for portfolio items
- **Google Tag Manager**: Analytics and tracking (referenced in index.html)
- **Social Media Platforms**: Instagram, Vimeo, Telegram, and VKontakte for external links

### Integration Points
- **RuTube API**: Embedded portfolio videos with iframe integration
- **Form Submissions**: Mini-brief form data collection and potential CRM integration
- **Analytics**: Event tracking system with `dataLayer` push pattern
- **Social Media**: Direct links to various social platforms

### Component Relationships
```mermaid
graph LR
  A[HTML Pages] --> B[CSS Styling]
  A --> C[JavaScript Functionality]
  A --> D[Media Assets]
  C --> E[Mobile Navigation]
  C --> F[Portfolio Filtering]
  C --> G[Accordion Toggles]
  C --> H[Form Handling]
  B --> I[Responsive Design]
  B --> J[Theming]
  D --> K[Video Content]
  D --> L[Image Assets]
  E --> M[User Experience]
  F --> M
  G --> M
  H --> M
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The landing page implements several key features to enhance user engagement and conversion:

- **Interactive Portfolio**: Filterable showcase of video work organized by category
- **Dynamic Pricing Information**: Expandable details for each service offering
- **Mobile-Optimized Navigation**: Hamburger menu with smooth transitions
- **Call-to-Action Elements**: Multiple conversion points throughout the site
- **Countdown Timer**: FOMO (fear of missing out) element for booking urgency
- **Modal Dialogs**: Mini-brief form for lead generation

### Implementation Highlights
- **Portfolio Filtering System**: Category-based filtering with visual feedback
- **Responsive Design**: Adapts seamlessly from mobile to desktop
- **Video Autoplay Handling**: Special logic for mobile video playback
- **Session Data Transfer**: Passing portfolio data between pages
- **Accessibility Features**: Proper ARIA labels and semantic HTML

### Feature Architecture
```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
  [*] --> HomePage
  HomePage --> PortfolioPage: Click Portfolio
  HomePage --> PricePage: Click Prices
  HomePage --> ContactPage: Click Contacts
  PortfolioPage --> FilteredView: Select Category
  FilteredView --> AllView: Select All
  PricePage --> ExpandedDetails: Click "Подробнее"
  PricePage --> ExamplesView: Click "Смотреть"
  HomePage --> MiniBrief: Click CTA
  MiniBrief --> Submitted: Form Submit
  Submitted --> Confirmation: Success
```

### UI Component Hierarchy
```mermaid
graph TD
  App[App Component] --> Header[Header]
  App --> Main[Main Content]
  App --> Footer[Footer]
  Header --> Logo[Logo]
  Header --> Nav[Navigation]
  Nav --> NavLink[Navigation Links]
  Main --> Hero[Hero Section]
  Hero --> Video[Background Video]
  Hero --> CTA[Call to Action]
  Main --> Services[Services Grid]
  Main --> Portfolio[Portfolio Preview]
  Main --> Team[Team Section]
  Main --> Consultation[Consultation Form]
  Footer --> Social[Social Icons]
  Footer --> Copyright[Copyright]
```

Sources:
- [index.html](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\index.html)
- [portfolio.html](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\portfolio.html)
- [price.html](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\price.html)
- [contact.html](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\contact.html)
- [founder.html](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\founder.html)
- [main.js](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\assets\main.js)
- [styles.css](c:\Users\bloom\OneDrive\Рабочий стол\РАБОТА\КНЯЗЕВ ПРО\Landing\assets\styles.css)
</blog>
